question: Do teaching hospitals have lower risk-adjusted mortality rates than non-teaching hospitals? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Other outcomes were diverse, but typically teaching healthcare structures did not do better than nonteaching ones.
content.source_2: Pooling adjusted estimates across cohorts, mortality was substantially lower in teaching hospitals (summary relative risk 0.88, 95% CI 0.84–0.92) compared with nonteaching facilities; minor teaching centers demonstrated a similar benefit (RR 0.95, 95% CI 0.91–0.99).
content.source_3: Conclusions The available data, although largely nonrandomized, suggest that a healthcare facility’s teaching status on its own markedly improves patient outcomes.
